values: Criminey! I've been such a slack-ass -- no art in a while. The good news is, I've got some coming. Hooray!
http://troll-art.livejournal.com/4454.html

As it would seem, what may be my only vacation for this year begins tomorrow. To keep myself from stressing about this week's sketches, I've opted to upload one of my recent completed projects, 'Daily Addictions'. This was my first experiment in process art, and thus a bit out of my style, but it called to my love of beautiful papers. The actual process involved treating my paper with coffee, food oils, heat, vodka, and cigarettes. I'm more proud of the paper than the images, so at a later date I'd love to continue with this process. I'd really love more ideas on what images I could use, or different spins on these. My main problem I ran into involved all my pens clogging up because of the oiled paper, so I didn't push things as far as I would have liked. And, if you couldn't guess, the piece was about the relationship between the objects displayed and the process of the paper.
http://troll-art.livejournal.com/3849.html

I admit, I'm late on this one. I totally fail. No excuses this time, though. Just two little sketches I thuroughly enjoyed working on this week. Okay. No moon. Just fish. And chickens. And Camerons. I've got an obsession with papers, and lately, I've just been fooling around with colored mediums vs. colored papers. This is white verithin prismacolor pencil on colored craft paper. Say hello to Petey the fish's portrait! Bwahahaha! All I have to say is Cameron said he wanted to see more involving the crazy chickens. So... he got it. Up close and personal. Cheap gouache, prisma pencils, and ink.
http://troll-art.livejournal.com/3630.html

This is the final take on a bookcover illustration, only the image is my work, the cover's text and format was a template used for the entire class once our images were complete. The assignment's guidelines asked for an image influenced by Poe's work and done entirely in chalk pastels (and cleanup in photoshop). My concept started with influences from The Masque of the Red Death and The Cask of Amontillado, although the final idea didn't necessarily represent anything in particular. This scan is quite bad, but it was the best I could manage for right now, and in general I wasn't terribly proud of my finished work. Pastels tend to frustrate me, and I have an intense loathing of anything with a chalky texture. But who knows... I learned a good bit about the medium and I'd like to do another pastel piece in the future.
http://troll-art.livejournal.com/3517.html

Ah, finally, sketches are here! Only four, yet again. I've gotten out of the habit of using my sketchbook over the summer so it's going to be another week or two before I can start updating with new sketches of the week. These first two were studies for a painting final where one draws a bunch of words out of a hat and has to illustrate them. As per usual with this type of assignment, my fellow classmates were unimaginative with their words and thus I had to cobble together something completely random. It resulted in something along the lines of a World of Warcraft troll with mechanical wings. Anyway, this gives a general idea of where I start when I'm working on the piece. And here we have my failed attempt at last week's illustration friday, which I only colored just today. It's pen, watercolor, and colored pencil on bristol, and the theme somehow traveled from "rain" to "rain of toast killing chickens!" I honestly don't know why. And lastly, something that's not actually a sketch... this is the first two layers of a self-portrait that will mimic the style of Brian Froud, one of my all-time favorite artists. Thus far I've sketched a basic outline of the setup, and covered that with a very thin coat of acylic which both seals the board from absorbing color permanently and creates my highlight color. Then, I've layered over a darker wash of watercolor which I'm now in the process of removing in the highlighted areas. Anyway, that's it for this week!
http://troll-art.livejournal.com/3101.html

Hidey ho, LJers!
 Just giving a heads up that due to having been stranded in Augusta, Georgia this past monday and today being the 4th of July, I've decided to postpone Sketchbook Tuesday until tomorrow. Which, I suppose, makes it Sketchbook Wednesday. Which sounds better. Hm.

Anyway, sketches tomorrow, and if time allows I'll be picking up work on Illustration Friday again. Huzzah!

-Briana
http://troll-art.livejournal.com/3001.html

Well, as of today my scanner is officially resurrected and I've procured my very first drafting table thanks to a kind and loving dad. Thanks, Dad!

And now, I really have no excuse to avoid working, so expect new things soon.
http://troll-art.livejournal.com/2670.html

or Another Futile Attempt To Look Like I'm Productive I've found that being in school is great for my productivity, what with assignments and side projects and the always possible death of one's grades and ensuing kicking of my ass by the parental units who fund said schooling experience. However, I'm not in school right now and I'm stuggling to find ways to keep myself productive in my art. So, until I find the Great And Mighty Answer to this delimma, I'm going to FOOL YOU ALL and just make you think I'm productive by creating Sketchbook Tuesdays. Ahh, Sketchbook Tuesdays. Where you must suffer through whatever random slop I throw at you and SMILE. [or, you know, not.] Let's travel newest to oldest this week, shall we? First, A sketch for a webcomic. Yeah, I'm like everyone else and aspiring to make my own sucessful webcomic. Shut it. Second, the original concept sketch for one of my most recent pieces: Dirty Mouth More attempts at cartoon styles. I need to finish this. And finally, a little something left over from highschool. Sophomore year, I think?
http://troll-art.livejournal.com/2359.html

Here's my submission for this week's IlloFriday theme: Spotted. I don't think I'm done here, yet. Something is definitely missing though I'm not entirely sure what. The eye color needs to pick up the purples and needs a highlight, and the hair could use some work. As to process, this is acrylic on illustration board, then a layer or watercolor, a wash of oil paint, and it was finished with acrylic and colored pencils.
http://troll-art.livejournal.com/2029.html

Here's my piece for this week's Illustration Friday word, Speed: Colored pencil on craft paper. Yet again, the scanner has washed out half my color. I'm thinking I'll have to start using a better scanner from now on, because it seems like all my favorite details are getting washed out when I use 's.
http://troll-art.livejournal.com/1598.html

For those who have been patiently waiting, and hopefully eagerly waiting, I bring you: BunBun's Bad Hare Day WARNING: Full text not enclosed. Until this book gets a good yea or nea on publishing, I won't be showing the entire story to the public. This project was far more about the images in the story, as it came from a study about patterns. I am not a writer! A full view of the accordian style binding: Pages 2 & 3: Pages 4 & 5: Pages 8 & 9: This is my first full attempt at illustrating a short children's book. The story itself was written by myself and Cam Cook, and I'm seeking some way to get the book published -- so any suggestions whould be helpful! The illustrations are ink on glassine paper, and I can provide further images after the 12th of April if requested. Woo!
http://troll-art.livejournal.com/1522.html
Just for something pretty to look at, I bring you... Pommegranate! This is Prismacolor Marker and Micron Pen on Drafting Vellum. Boder added in Photoshop.
http://troll-art.livejournal.com/1033.html

Here's my submission for this week's Illustration Friday word: Spring. I'm not terribly thrilled with it. I was having trouble getting the images to where I wanted them, and then when I scanned the image it completely washed out the entire piece. This is just an attempt at restoring the original color, and it didn't go terribly well. The original idea was really fun, though. I like working with lots of layers of color and just playing with my materials, so this is one I'll probably revisit sometime soon. I'd love to hear opinions on what I could have added or worked on, because this one just left me feeling utterly unfulfilled and aggrivated. As for particulars, this is Windsor and Newton watercolor with Prismacolor Colored Pencils layered over top on Strathmore illustration board, and touch-ups were done it photoshop. But, of course, Hooray Bunnies!
http://troll-art.livejournal.com/950.html

Here's my very first submission to Illustration Friday: "Simple" I know it's terribly basic, but I'm only now getting my 'legs' for illustration, and I've been fumbling about with Photoshop which has only been going... interestingly. I started out with a basic black ink outline, filled in the color with prismacolor colored pencils, and tooled around with the background in Photoshop. All in all, it's about an hour or less worth of work and worthy of the theme "simple." On a random side note, I'm addicted to naming everything, so for anyone wanting to indulge in my mini-psychosis -- the Koala's name is Bartleby and the Turtle is Jacob. They wage a war for pie, which is a noble endeavor. Atleast, I like to think so.
http://troll-art.livejournal.com/749.html

Basically, I had an art blog set up at Blogger.com and found out that I absolutely loathe their setup. So, as is tradition, I've run back to LiveJournal -- my home sweet home here on the web. Over the course of the next week I'll move my old entries over to here and start updating with some of the other illustrations that I have laying around. This Blog has been created for me to flush out my learning as an art student and to get people to see what I'm doing, so always feel free to post any criticisms or comments or link others to this site. And with that... Salut! -Briana
http://troll-art.livejournal.com/311.html
